intro: Triticum compactum grex erinaceum, commonly known as the goat grass, is a wild wheat species native to the Mediterranean region. It is characterized by its compact growth habit and the presence of a dense, bristle-like awn on its seeds, giving it the name "erinaceum," which means hedgehog in Latin. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and has narrow, grass-like leaves. Its flowers are small and arranged in spikes, typical of the Poaceae family. It is often found in disturbed soils and is considered a forage plant for livestock.
